questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to OPD with his lower limb X- rays. X Rays show increased osteo density all over the bone. All of the following conditions show increased osteo density except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Osteomalacia Osteomalacia doesn’t show increased osteo density; rather, insufficiency fractures are seen. The word osteomalacia primarily means softening bones due to a vitamin D deficiency in adults. These patients may present with fractures known as Pseudofracture / Increment Fracture / Milk man’s fracture / Osteoid seams/’Osteoid zones / Umbauzanones/ Looser’s zones, / Looser’s lines.

Highyeild:

Osteomalacia - occurs due to Vit. D. deficiency in adults The basic meaning of word osteomalacia is softening of bones which occurs due to deficiency of vitamin D in adults. These patients may present with fractures which are known as Pseudofracture / Increment Fracture / Milk man's fracture /Osteoid seams/'Osteoid zones / Umbauzanones/ Looser's zones / Looser's lines. Clinical features can be bone pain, muscle pain, proximal muscle weakness, gate disturbances, or pseudo fractures. These represent incomplete (insufficiency) fractures that have healed by callus consisting of osteoid tissue lacking calcium (i.e. unmineralized woven bone). HYP Differential diagnosis for pseudo fractures Osteomalacia and Rickets (most characteristic) Chronic renal tubular disease (cause hypophosphatemia) Phenobarbitones, diphenylhydantoin Glomerular disease (cause PO4 retention and hyper phosphatemia) ه Hereditary hyperphosphatasia Renal osteodystrophy Vitamin A intoxication Cadmium poisoning Congenital hypophosphatasia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Paget’s disease (osteitis deformans) : - both increased, and decreased osteo density may be seen depending upon the phase of the disease. Option: B. Osteopetrosis (marble bone disease): - a result of decreased osteoclast function- failure of bone resorption. Option: C. Osteopoikilosis (spotted bone disease): - islands of deep cortical bone appear within the medullary cavity.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a disease that hardens bone due to vitamin D deficiency
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a disease that hardens bone due to vitamin D deficiency It is a disease that hardens bone due to vitamin D deficiency. It is a disease that softens bone due to vitamin D deficiency, as it is an essential mineral of bone formation. It is a disease of a growing skeleton. Because of a lack of minerals for new bone formation – osteoid (a soft part of the bone) is laden up at the growth plate. Because bones are soft -- metaphyseal widening, cupping, and splaying are seen in X-ray pictures.

Highyeild:

Earliest manifestation is seen in skull Craniotabes is a softening of the cranial bones and can be detected by applying pressure at the occiput or over the parietal bones. The sensation is similar to the feel of pressing into a ping-pong ball and then releasing. Craniotabes may also be secondary to osteogenesis imperfecta, hydrocephalus, and syphilis. It is a normal finding in many new born, especially near the suture lines, but it typically disappears within a few months of birth. Chest Widening of the costochondral junctions results in a rachitic rosary, which feels like the beads of a rosary as the examiner's fingers move along the costochondral junctions from rib to rib. Growth plate widening is also responsible for the enlargement at the wrists and ankles. The horizontal depression along the lower anterior chest known as Harrison groove occurs from pulling of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during inspiration. Softening of the ribs also impairs air movement and predisposes patients to atelectasis and pneumonia. Short stature & bowing of long bones, with genu valgum, coxa vara or windswept deformities of legs (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg). Generalized muscular weakness, lethargy and irritability, listlessness, tetany or convulsions. Protuberant abdomen with separation of recti muscles (muscular flaccidity) Large head, open fontanelles & craniotabes (box shaped head) Thickening of knees, ankle, & wrists physeal overgrowth (enlargement). Pectus carinatum i.e. forward projection of sternum Delayed dentition with irregular soft decaying teeth (enamel defect). Pale skin, flabby subcutaneous tissue & typical widened look. Radiographic Findings The characteristic features of rickets are Thickening & widening of growth plate (physis) Indistinct and hazy metaphysis that is abnormally wide with cupping or flaring. (Brush like appearance) Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices. Looser's zone can be seen in 15-20%

Harrison's sulcus, rachitic rosary, and deformities like knock knee or bow legs are other essential features. Option: B. Primary treatment is a high dose of vitamin D. Primary treatment is a high dose of vitamin D, around 6 lakh unit oral dose. If the line of healing -- sclerotic line at the metaphyseal side of the growth plate is not seen on an X-ray within 3-4 weeks, the same dose can be repeated. If a child responds to treatment , a maintenance dose of vitamin D 400 units per day will be given. If a child doesn't respond to treatment, it comes under refractory rickets, which a multispecialty team should evaluate. Option: D. Sometimes, it requires surgical treatment to correct the deformity Moderate or severe deformities often require surgical correction in the form of corrective osteotomy. This can be performed after 6 months of starting proper medical treatment.

questions.text: A lady brings her 5-year-old girl to Ortho OPD for evaluation of knocked knees and short stature. On clinical examination, the child walks with a circumduction gait and falls frequently. Her x-ray was done. On blood investigations, calcium 9 mg/dl, phosphorus 2.4 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 550 U/L, 25-OH vitamin D 45 ng/mL (RR 25-50 ng/mL), 1,25-OH vitamin D 22 pg/mL (RR 24-86 pg/mL), PTH 35 pg/mL (RR 15-65 pg/mL). The child is adopted and family history is not known. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Familial hypophosphatemic rickets This patient has genu valgum secondary to familial hypophosphatemic rickets (FHR) , an X- linked dominant disorder caused by the inability of renal tubules to absorb phosphate resulting in low serum phosphorus, high alkaline phosphatase , low 1,25-OH vitamin D (1,25OHD) in the setting of normal serum calcium, 25-OH vitamin D (25OHD) and PTH.

Highyeild:

Rickets is a disorder characterised by defective mineralisation of the growth plate. It can result from nutritional deficiency, genetic defects in renal phosphate absorption (FHR) or the formation/action of 1,25-OH vitamin D, or renal dysfunction. Treatment of FHR includes medical management with calcitriol (1,25-OH vitamin D), as well as surgical correction of lower limb deformities with either hemiepiphysiodesis/guided growth (age < 11 years old) or corrective osteotomies (age > 11-years-old). Given X-Ray is a radiograph of the bilateral knees and a skeletally immature patient showing widening of the physeal plates and metaphyseal cupping, which is pathognomonic of rickets.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Nutritional rickets is characterised by low calcium , low 25 OH D, and high PTH. Option: B. Renal osteodystrophy is characterised by low calcium, high phosphorus, low 25 OH D, and high PTH. Option: D. While Osteogenesis Imperfecta can cause osteopenia and limb deformity, the abnormal laboratory data is more suggestive of rickets.

Low serum phosphate, elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated PTH The key laboratory factor that differentiates nutritional from hypophosphatemic rickets is an elevated PTH .
